title: Robert Evans' extraordinary life of scandal and mob allegations as he dies aged 89
text:

The profile of slick movie mogul Robert Evans in a 1969 article captured him perfectly.

“The playboy peacock of Paramount,” read the magazine feature about the flamboyant Hollywood producer behind The Godfather.

The perma-tanned legend was pictured lounging self-importantly amid crumpled bed sheets and film scripts, breakfast tray askew, barking orders down a phone.

“He is entirely too good-looking, too rich, too young, lucky and too damned charming.”

It continued: “Who the hell does he think he is? If there’s anything Hollywood wants out of Robert Evans, it’s to see him fail.”

Hollywood ultimately got its wish – and then some. The greased-haired, turtleneck-wearing Evans, the ultimate old-school movie boss caricature, was to eventually fall spectacularly.

(Image: Getty)

(Image: Getty)

He buckled not only beneath film failure and meteoric fortune loss in the 1980s – in 10 years he dropped from a worth of $11million to $37 – but also scandal as salacious than anything his films could muster.

First, a drug addiction and a conviction for cocaine trafficking, and allegations of a real-life mob-style murder.

Then too, there was the disastrous love life of the “peacock”– no less than seven failed marriages, one lasting nine days, another destroyed by the advances of love rival Steve McQueen.

For the philanderer who ushered a string of leading ladies rumoured to include Grace Kelly and Raquel Welch beneath his mink bedspread, some would argue it was little less than he deserved.

But ultimately, when Evans died on Saturday aged 89, he wasn’t a failure and wasn’t disliked. Somehow, he had bounced back, with a best-selling autobiography and a revived film career.

(Image: imdb)

(Image: WireImage)

Despite all the shenanigans, he was respected in the film industry as a legend. Perhaps it was because whatever else he was, he was always himself.

Once asked who his favourite character was, he replied: “Popeye. ‘I yam what I yam. That’s all what I yam.’”

Born Robert J Shapira to a Jewish dentist in New York on June 29, 1930 – Evans was adopted in honour of his paternal grandmother’s maiden name – he quickly warmed to the limelight.

He had a talent for mimicry, and aged 14 landed himself a slot on a radio show, and was later taken on as a trainee actor by Paramount. But he was dropped six months later and started selling women’s trousers with his brother’s clothing business.

Perhaps the salesman in him was always his greatest gift. The business took off and he boasted “women were responsible for making me a millionaire by my twenties”.

(Image: Getty)

(Image: Zoetrope Pictures)

But his big break into acting was still to come. In 1956, he was lounging by the pool at the Beverley Hills Hotel when he was spotted by MGM film star Norma Shearer who decided the good-looking lad was perfect to play her late husband, Irving Thalberg, in Man of a Thousand Faces.

Later that year, Evans was also cast as a bullfighter alongside Ava Gardner in The Sun Also Rises.

Cocky Evans wasn’t actually that good – even Ava wanted him dropped.

But director Darryl F Zanuck famously declared: “The kid stays in the picture” – a tagline which would follow Evans for the rest of his life.

Evans, however, recognised his talents lay elsewhere and decided he “wanted to be the guy who makes the decisions, not the guy who has the decisions made for him”.

(Image: Paramount)

(Image: Getty)

He craved Zanuck’s power, and by 1966 had convinced Paramount to make him head of production.

The Odd Couple, then Rosemary’s Baby – directed by Roman Polanski who he “discovered” – followed.

Then came hits True Grit with John Wayne, Love Story with Ali MacGraw and Ryan O’Neal, and Robert Redford’s The Great Gatsby.

Evans helped transform Paramount’s fortunes, and the successes trailblazed a lavish lifestyle. A French Regency mansion in Beverly Hills came complete with a cinema where an English butler served guests including pals Jack Nicholson and Warren Beatty brandy – and the next morning reminded Evans of the names of the ladies who’d slept over.

Meanwhile, “the peacock” was in and out of nuptials faster than directing suites. He once cockily described himself as a “ladies’ man” who was sensitive to “a ‘void’ most women share” – the need for “a male embracer – not sex, affirmation”. Actress wives Sharon Hugueny and Camilla Sparv came and went. But number three, actress Ali MacGraw, star of Love Story, and mother of Evans’ son Josh, was thought to be the love of his life.

“Her lethal embrace, her extraordinary affection, love, affirmation, fetching femininity, caress to family and friends, gave me an adrenaline I never thought I had,” said Evans. They married in 1969, but she left him after falling under Steve McQueen’s spell on the set of The Getaway in 1972.

(Image: Getty)

(Image: GC Images)

Bizarrely, Evans, ever the social animal, was pals with Henry Kissinger, who reportedly said: “If I can negotiate with the North Vietnamese I think I can smooth the way with Ali.”

But Evans stoically replied: “Henry, you know countries but you don’t know women. When it’s over, it’s over.”

Wife No4 Miss America Phyllis George, lasted less than a year. And the fifth came 20 years later, and was the briefest of all – he and Dynasty actress Catherine Oxenberg met as he recovered from a stroke, and parted after just nine days, still pals.

She was followed by Leslie Ann Woodward, then Lady Victoria White, who divorced him in 2006.

Evans wasn’t too keen on monogamy, he admitted. Something Sylvester Stallone could attest to. He once claimed Evans told him they had something in common, then produced a “very X-rated polaroid” of Stallone’s girlfriend, naked.

But while his love life was chequered, Evans’ career continued to be golden for a while.

(Image: Getty)

The Godfather, for which he insisted on hiring mainly Italian-Americans – “I want to smell the spaghetti” – became the No.1 hit of 1972, winning three Academy Awards.

It was Evans’ influential mob fixer pal, Sidney Korshak, once an advisor to gangster Al Capone, who leant on the right people to get Al Pacino out of a contract at Evans’ demand so he could star in it. With no choice, Pacino’s agent yelled down the phone at Evans: “The midget’s yours.”

After seven years with Paramount, Evans was itching to set up an independent studio, and became the first actor to do so. Movies like Chinatown and Marathon Man followed, but dogged by cocaine addiction, in 1980, he was implicated in a drug-buying bust, pleaded guilty to misdemeanour drug charges and was put on probation. He later said the episode turned his life “to one of disgrace”.

Meanwhile, films failed, most fabulously Harlem dance club film The Cotton Club. In 1983 its financial backer, Roy Radin, was murdered. His bullet-riddled body found stuffed with dynamite.

Evans had been introduced to him by Karen DeLayne Greenberger, a West Coast cocaine trafficker, who he admitted to an affair with. In 1991 she and three others were found guilty of the murder. Evans was never charged but his reputation was ruined.

He recalled: “The lowest point of my life was being at my son Josh’s graduation and the headline in the newspaper that day was that Bob Evans was involved in the Cotton Club murder.”

Depression followed, and he was forced to sell his estate – until pal Nicholson bought it back for him.

These failures didn’t prove the end for Evans. In 1991 he returned to

Paramount, producing films including The Saint and his final credit, 2003’s How To Lose A Guy In 10 Days. Evans then remarked: “I’m a little battered. But I like myself. For not selling out.”
description: The Hollywood producer lived a life more salacious than anything his films could muster, from drug addiction and a conviction for cocaine trafficking to allegations of a real-life mob-style murder
